Last June, the Senate Appropriations Committee – by a bipartisan majority vote – approved $1.6 billion for Fiscal Year 2019 to construct approximately 65 miles of pedestrian fencing in the Rio Grande Valley Sector in Texas along our southern border.

Last March, Speaker Pelosi and 110 of her Democratic colleagues in the House voted to approve $1.6 billion for Fiscal Year 2018 for over 90 miles of physical barrier construction along our southern border.

In October 2006, Congress approved the Secure Fence Act.  It passed the House 283-138 and later the Senate by 80-19.  Senators voting in favor included Sens. Obama, Biden, Boxer, Feinstein, Clinton, and Schumer.

In 1996, President Bill Clinton signed the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 (P.L. 104-208), which expressly authorized the construction and improvement of fencing and other barriers along the Southwest border.

Constructing a physical barrier on our southern border has historically received bipartisan support. So why are Democrats now digging their heels in over a difference of $3.4 billion, which represents 0.26% of our discretionary budget, for something they’ve supported in the past?
It’s an honor and a privilege to be sworn into the 116th Congress. I pledge to defend the Constitution while fighting for policies that benefit our district, state and nation.
